awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  SHINE:  Characteristics of Solar Energetic Particle Events Resulting from Filament Eruptions
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the details of solar energetic particle (SEP) acceleration is critical for accurate predictions of space weather and potential impacts on sensitive space-based assets.  This 3-year SHINE project is aimed at studying SEP events associated with filament eruptions on the Sun.  The goal is to isolate and investigate SEPs accelerated at CME-driven shocks with minimal flare material contributions.  The work expands on other researchers' recent results by using more instruments to cover a broader energy range and extend the analysis.  The methodology involves spectral and elemental composition data analysis techniques that are well established.  The dissemination of the scientific results will be made broadly to the scientific and space weather prediction communities through published articles, scientific talks, and personal communications.  In addition, project results and relevant data sets will be made available via the public web pages of the ACE and STEREO Science Centers.  The three project teams have excellent track record of publications, participating (often in leadership roles) in various workshops (e.g., SHINE), and attending scientific conferences.  Both the team leader and a Co-PIs are under-represented minorities and funding is included for the involvement of an undergraduate student.  The project will promote strong international collaborations for the benefit of advancing space weather research both in the USA and worldwide.
  
The research plan of this 3-year SHINE project includes four main tasks.  The first task is to examine the characteristics of heavy ions for previously identified events.  The spectral shape variation as a function of particle species reveals characteristics of the accelerating shock, while the composition provides important clues regarding the SEP seed population.  The second task is to study smaller SEP events associated with filament eruptions by using the more sensitive SEP sensors onboard ACE and STEREO.  The inclusion of STEREO data alone has the potential to increase the number of events suitable for study and, in combination with near-Earth spacecraft, allows the examination of SEP characteristics as a function of longitude.  The third task is to define stronger constrains on the primary acceleration region by combining calculations of the particle-release times, for both for single-and multiple-spacecraft events, with timing of the corresponding solar signatures.  The fourth task is to study in detail similar filament eruption events without associated SEP events in order to identify specific features that are key to SEP generation.  The project is directly relevant to the NSF's SHINE program, because it will provide important knowledge about the acceleration and transport of SEPs during solar eruptive events.  Such knowledge is critical for accurate modeling and prediction of space weather conditions from the solar surface to the Earth and beyond.  The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of our project was to enhance our understanding of the relative roles of flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs) in accelerating solar energetic particles (SEPs) by studying a newly classified group of SEPs (filament eruption SEPs or FE SEPs; Gopalswamy et al. 2015) that are associated with filament eruptions. Our major goals are:

1. Examine the spectral shape variation as a function of particle species to reveal characteristics of the accelerating shock, examine the composition for clues regarding the SEP seed population.

2. Use more sensitive SEP sensors on ACE and STEREO to look for more FE SEP events. Examine longitudinal extent of FE SEPs in comparison with typical SEP events.

3. Calculate particle release time combined with timing of the solar signatures to place stronger constrains on the primary acceleration region.

4. Study similar filament eruption events without associated SEP events to identify specific features that are key to SEP generation.

Most SEP events are produced by flares and CMEs erupting at active regions, which are areas of strong magnetic fields on the solar surface. Active regions often have sunspots and are the main source of solar activity. Occasionally, SEP events are associated with CMEs involving filament eruption (FE) outside of active regions. Filaments (also called prominences when viewed above the limb of the solar disk) are long narrow structures containing cool plasma suspended by magnetic fields, which sometimes become unstable and are ejected from the Sun. In our study we compare the FE-associated SEP events with the more common SEP events originating from the active regions.

Our study has resulted in some new information and data sets, and some supporting information for some existing theories. We have compiled a list containing almost all of the FEs and the associated CMEs, SEP events, and radio bursts from the Sun during 2006-2014. We used data from GOES, SDO, SOHO, STEREO, SAMPEX and WIND spacecraft. We studied characteristics of these events to investigate the difference between filament eruptions associated with SEP events and those without. We found that interplanetary type II radio bursts that are produced by CME-driven shocks were present in SEP-associated filament eruption events while non-SEP filament eruption events lacked type II association. We also identified at least one SEP event that has the characteristics of SEP acceleration by shock that is formed away from the active region. This was associated with a prominence. Other properties such as speed and filament length were similar in the two quiescent and SEP-associated FEs. However, the CMEs were more massive and had greater kinetic energy in SEP-associated filament eruption events. This supports the idea that CME-driven shock is the source of SEP events.

A broader impact of this project was in providing research and professional development opportunities to three young scientists of whom two as female scientists are from an under-represented group. This professional development activity consists of learning identification of filament eruptions, their locations and associations with active regions, and is carried out by consulting other senior researchers. The project provided also opportunities to present our results in front of audiences at a variety of international conferences. Developing self-confidence while presenting good quality research to peers and experts is a major achievement.  The PI is now a full-time faculty in a local community college and is actively involved in training community college students to do research in space and solar physics. This is of high importance because community faculty and students are typically under-represented in STEM research due to very limited access to opportunities. She has introduced the topics of FEs, CMEs, SEPs, and space weather to her students in class and research projects; and that is a unique development opportunity for community college students, who do not get much exposure to space science research otherwise.

Therefore, our project carried out scientific study as proposed, trained staff scientists and a community college female faculty, and also brought the training and development to community college students who will be our future STEM workforce.
